Hi,

> > * Less data makes each situation less-unique (ooh, an oxymoron!),
> which
> > makes strategies more generic.
> 
> I take it that English is not your first language? I am truly humbled.

Why thank you. No, english isn't my first language, but I'm familiar with
many kinds of morons, oxegenated or otherwise. ;)
 
> > The question is - which indicators to use and what fitness function
> to
> > use. I tried a dozen different fitness functions also. Max drawdown,
> max
> > profit, max profit / max drawdown etc.
> 
> Ah, the fitness function, there indeed is the rub. Could some sort of
> Chi-squared function be applied to determine statistical significance
> of the results?

Possibly, I'm not really familiar with chi-squared though I looked it up
right now.

[Snip]
> I think these may have a permanent
> effect on markets, such that rules that were applicable before are
> potentially lethal (in a financial sense) after. 

Yes, but not only actual events carry this risk, trading conditions can
change for no particular reason, as when the market moves from bull/bear
to a sideways market.

> Using daily data then
> severely restricts the amount of history that can safely be used.

Ah, yes, changes to legislation that mean that trading has forever changed
will invalidate all old data. But I'm not sure that the short term trading
is thus affected. Though I'll say this; trading _has_ changed the last
couple of years. Everyone trades with an online broker these days, and
they're far more active then ever before. This didn't used to be the case
and arguably things have changed since before - say - 1998?

However, I feel that there are probably a number a modes of trading that
the market place moves between, and individual stocks can exist in a
different mode from the rest of the marketplace. Thus, you want your
training set to contain the mode that's going to prevail in the immediate
future. Since you don't know what mode that is, and at what times in the
past that mode was active, you're forced to include all modes.

Sounds complex, but in reality, I think that adding many years of data
would be enough. You want bull, bear, booms, total busts and sideways
markets in the data set, cause either one of them could be next.

Sadly, this is never going to be as profitable as including a more limited
number of modes, or only the mode that's active at the time.

> Perhaps a candidate input might be the time since a major shock was
> experienced, which might help the model decide when it's learned
> enough about the way the market has changed. I'd expect that recurrent
> networks would be a big help here.

I was forced to give up recurence (or it's GP equivalent) for practical
purposes in my previous attempts, but I'll try to investigate it again.

> I think to get the full benefit of
> this the network shouldn't be iterated for each set of inputs until it
> reaches some kind of "steady state", rather that each set of inputs
> consitututes one "tick" in the evaluation.

This sounds interesting.

> > I'm not saying that AI trading isn't possible though...
> 
> I'm utterly convinced that it is - I've worked with too many traders
> to believe that most of them couldn't be replaced with a reasonably
> well-written program!

lol!

cheers,
mattias
